item.title: Arc Raiders player calls for help during game, gets door kicked-in by concerned neighbour
item.content:encoded:
An Arc Raiders player calling for help while playing the game had their door kicked in by a concerned neighbour, who thought their wails were a sign of real-world distress.

User Dreamthorp on the Arc Raiders Reddit was house-sitting for a friend and decided to boot up some Arc Raiders. While playing ,they claim to have been calling to their squadmates for help when a nearby neighbour heard the commotion. Fearing the worst, they came to the rescue, kicking the door.

Thankfully, the door didn't break thanks to the two deadbolts keeping it locked and secure. Dreamthorp claims that the friend they were house-sitting finds the whole situation funny, and the whole story has a happy ending, with Dreamthorp posting a picture of a six-pack of Shiners left at the neighbour's door as thanks.

Arc Raiders continues its hot streak as both a top seller over the Christmas holiday and one of the most popular games out right now, players remain engaged with its blend of hyper aggressive extraction-style PvP gameplay and the interesting social dynamics present in an otherwise perilous experience.

As for what's to come in 2026 for Arc Raiders? There's still little in terms of official confirmation on what's coming up for the game following its winter Cold Snap event. With the year well underway, there's no doubt big news for Arc Raiders is just around the corner.

If you're curious about Arc Raiders, why not read Eurogamer's review! In it, Rick Lane wrote: "Rich PvE combat and an unusually friendly community make Arc Raiders a more approachable extraction shooter than most, but Embark Studios' continued use of AI voice generation is a black mark against its reputation."

item.title: Surprise! Xbox Game Pass has added two more games, as five others get ready to leave the service soon
item.content:encoded:
Beauty is in the eye of the controller.

The team over at Xbox has added two previously unannounced games to its Game Pass subscription service.

Game Pass subscribers can now play Little Nightmares Enhanced Edition and Brews and Bastards through the service. These two titles were not previously said to be coming when Microsoft laid out its most recent Game Pass line-up plans.

Little Nightmares Enhanced Edition and Brews and Bastards join the likes of Dome Keeper and other recent Xbox Game Pass additions.

To see this content please enable targeting cookies.

Little Nightmares Enhanced Edition is a remaster of the unsettling puzzle platformer, which tells the tale of a yellow-raincoated girl named Six, as she attempts to escape The Maw. That is to say, a strange underwater vessel inhabited by a multitude of bizarre residents.

The adventure was warmly received on release, with Edwin Evans-Thirlwell calling it a "masterpiece of meat and malice" in Eurogamer's Little Nightmares review.

Brews and Bastards, meanwhile, is described as an "intoxicating" dungeon crawler, which developer Mune Studio says is "overflowing with action-packed combat, potent brews and outlandish bosses". Players will need to choose an "inebriated" hero to then make their way through "hordes of drunken demons" as they try to search for the stolen Brew Stone.

As well as these two new Game Pass additions, Xbox has also detailed five games that will be leaving the service in the coming weeks. These are Neon White, Road 96, Flintlock: The Siege of Dawn, The Grinch: Christmas Adventures - Merry and Mischievous Edition and The Ascent.

For everything else in Microsoft's subscription service, you can check out our handy Xbox Game Pass guide detailing the many titles available.

Hunger

PS4, Xbox One, PC, Nintendo Switch

Related topics

item.title: One of the best action games released in recent memory is getting a special re-release soon
item.content:encoded:
Hi-Fi Rush, the most recent game from Tango Gameworks, is getting a special re-release in collaboration with Limited Run Games.

With pre-orders set to open from 16th January up until the 1st March, Hi-Fi Rush Rhythm Edition will feature the deluxe version of the game alongside three special DLC costumes. These costumes are the Bossplay, Traditional Garb, and Teamplay outfits. It'll be available for the Xbox Series X/S and PS5.

Extra keen fans go opt for an even grander package with the Hi-Fi Rush Smidge Edition. This features the same Deluxe version of the game and DLC costumes, alongside a special three disc soundtrack, developer notes, and a custom box designed after the tutorial robot present in the game. There's also a bunch of in-game skins and gears for gameplay upgrades.

Then there's an even bolder option, the Project Armstrong Edition. This contains everything in the Smidge Edition alongside an 808 plush, a small replica of Chai's guitar, a Chai Project Armstrong pass, a glow-in-the-dark MP3 player pin, an hard cover art book, and an individually numbered certificate of authenticity.

Both the Smidge and Project Armstrong Edition will be going up for pre-order during the same period as the regular Rhythm Edition, and prices for each are viewable on the Limited Run website. The Rhythm Edition will sell for $39.99, the Smidge Edition for $69.99, and the Project Armstrong Edition for $174.99.

Hi-Fi Rush has been through something of a journey over the past few years. Dropping suddenly back in 2023, the game proved an exceptional release, receiving ample critical praise. Its developer, Tango Gameworks, was later shut down by Microsoft as part of widespread cuts, which Xbox executive Matt Booty stated was partly due to the studio's leadership change, as Shinji Mikami left shortly after Hi-Fi Rush's release.

The studio would then be saved by Krafton, who acquired the team shortly after. Late last year, Krafton would then declare itself an "AI-first company".

Related topics
